questions.text: In the liver, the Apo-B gene is completely translated to Apo B-100 and in the intestine, it is translated to Apo B-48. Which of the following mechanisms explains this?

questions.text: Which of the following helps in maturation of collagen?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ascorbic acid Hydroxylation of proline and lysine takes place intracellularly as a part of post-translational modification with the help of prolyl and lysyl hydroxylase. These enzymes require iron in the reduced state. Vitamin C/Ascorbic acid keeps iron in a reduced state. Deficiency of Vit C leads to scurvy.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes uses molecular oxygen as a hydrogen acceptor to produce water?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Cytochrome C oxidase Cytochrome C oxidase catalyses the removal of hydrogen from a substrate using oxygen as a hydrogen acceptor and produces water as a reaction product. Cytochrome C is the terminal complex (complex 4) of the chain of respiratory carriers in the inner mitochondrial membrane. It is inhibited by cyanide, hydrogen sulphide, and carbon monoxide.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to cause Beriberi?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Vegan diet Beriberi is caused due to prolonged thiamine deficiency. Thiamine deficiency is more common due to chronic alcohol intake, chronic use of diuretics, patients who have had bariatric surgery. Prolonged thiamine deficiency can manifest as: 1. Wet beriberi- congestive heart failure and peripheral edema 2. Dry beriberi- neurological deficits Diagnosis of thiamine deficiency can be assessed by RBC Transketolase activity.

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition shown in the graph
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Non-competitive inhibition The above graph is a double reciprocal or Lineweaver-Burk plot of non-competitive inhibition. Non-competitive inhibition- when the substrate and the inhibitor are chemically not similar and have different shapes, the inhibitor binds away from the active site, at the allosteric site. In Non-competitive inhibition, Vmax decreases and Km remains constant. Competitive inhibition- here the inhibitor is a structural analogue of the substrate and competes with it to bind to the active site. Here Vmax is unchanged and Km is increased.

questions.text: Which source and cell produces testosterone?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Cholesterol and Leydig cells Testosterone production is mainly contributed by Leydig cells from cholesterol. Testosterone is also synthesised by adrenal cortex from androstenedione. Actions of testosterone: Development of secondary sexual characteristics in males, increase protein synthesis, maintain spermatogenesis along with FSH and increase libido.

questions.text: A young male presented with yellowish discolouration of the skin and sclera. He is otherwise normal. He gives history of viral infection 10 days ago which resolved 2 days bacl. He also gives similar history in the past following any illness. Lab values are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? S. bilirubin- 2.4mg/dl Unconjugated bilirubin- 2.1mg/dl Conjugated bilirubin- 0.3mg/dl Serum AST and ALT: Normal
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Gilbert syndrome The patient has mild jaundice seen only during a period of stress along with increased unconjugated bilirubin, and normal AST, ALT levels strongly point towards a diagnosis of Gilbert syndrome. Gilbert syndrome is a benign, AR disorder characterised by mild jaundice during periods of stress or illness. Dubin Johnson syndrome is also benign , AR but characterised by conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and brown-black pigment deposition in the liver. Criggler Najar syndrome is of 2 types, Type 1 has absent UDP Glucoronyltransferase production and Type 2 has <10% of the normal enzyme activity. Rotor syndrome is similar to Dubin Johnson syndrome but with a milder presentation. Liver does not show black colour.

questions.text: Composition of lactulose:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Lactulose is a synthetic disaccharide. It is not naturally found in foods. It's produced commercially from lactose (which is glucose + galactose) through an isomerization process. Here's why the other options are incorrect: A. Glucose + Galactose: This is the composition of lactose, the sugar found in milk, not lactulose. B. Glucose + Fructose: This is the composition of sucrose (table sugar). D. Fructose + ribulose: Ribulose is a pentose sugar, and a disaccharide composed of fructose and ribulose is not a common or recognized composition for lactulose.

questions.text: Which of the following is the rate limiting enzyme of heme synthesis pathway?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) ?-Amino Levulenic Acid (ALA) synthase. This enzyme holds the crucial role of the rate-limiting step in the heme synthesis pathway. It catalyzes the condensation reaction between glycine and succinyl-CoA, forming ?-aminolevulinic acid. This initial reaction is highly regulated, acting as the primary control point for the entire heme biosynthetic process. The body tightly controls ALA synthase activity to ensure appropriate heme levels, preventing both deficiency and harmful accumulation of intermediates. Its regulation involves both transcriptional control, where heme itself can repress the enzyme's synthesis, and feedback inhibition by heme, thus maintaining cellular heme homeostasis.

questions.text: A 2 year old child presents with bow legs, normal calcium, high PTH. The probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The most probable diagnosis in a 2-year-old child presenting with bow legs, normal calcium levels, and high PTH is rickets, specifically nutritional rickets due to vitamin D deficiency. Bow legs (genu varum) are a classic clinical sign in toddlers with rickets due to defective mineralization of the growing bone. In vitamin D deficiency, calcium absorption from the gut is reduced. The body compensates by increasing parathyroid hormone (PTH), which maintains serum calcium by increasing bone resorption and renal reabsorption of calcium. Hence, calcium remains in the normal range, but PTH is elevated, and phosphate is typically low. The image clearly shows the bowing of the legs, further supporting rickets as the diagnosis. Incorrect Option: A. Scurvy Scurvy, or vitamin C deficiency, affects collagen synthesis and presents with features like bleeding gums, petechiae, joint tenderness, and pseudoparalysis, but it does not cause bow legs or elevated PTH. Calcium and phosphate levels are generally normal in scurvy, making this an unlikely diagnosis. Incorrect Option: C. Hyperparathyroidism Primary hyperparathyroidism is extremely rare in children, and it usually presents with high calcium, low phosphate, and very high PTH. In this case, the child has normal calcium, making primary hyperparathyroidism an unlikely cause. Incorrect Option: D. Diabetes insipidus Diabetes insipidus affects water balance, causing polyuria, polydipsia, and dehydration. It has no link with bone deformities, calcium or PTH levels, and therefore is not relevant to the clinical picture of bow legs and elevated PTH.

questions.text: Which gene is mutated in Marfan’s Syndrome
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Fibrillin-1 Fibrillin-1 is found in: • Periosteum of long bones • Zonules of the lens • Walls of Large Blood Vessels. Fibrillin-1 has an inhibitory action on TGF-?, ensuring orderly arrangement of ECM components. In absence/defect of Fibrillin-1, TGF-? levels rise resulting in abnormal deposition of normal collagen affecting all the areas where Fibrillin-1 is normally present in large amounts resulting in: • Increase in length of long bones: Arachnodactyly (Periosteum of long bones) • Dislocation of lens (Zonules of the lens) • Coarctation of aorta (Walls of Large Blood Vessels) Fibrillin-2 is primarily active in intrauterine stage of life and is associated with “Congenital Contractural Arachnodactyly”

questions.text: Lactic Acidosis due to deficiency of which vitamin?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Thiamine The three common important cause of Lactic Acidosis due to inhibition of Pyruvate Dehydrogenase Complex are: 1. Inhibitors like arsenite and mercuric ions; inhibit lipoic acid, one of the coenzymes of the complex. 2. Thiamine (required as another coenzyme in the complex in the form of TPP) deficiency, commonly seen in chronic alcoholics due to two reasons: a. Poor dietary intake b. Inhibition of absorption of Thiamine by alcohol 3. Inherited deficiency of E1 of the complex (E1 =Pyruvate Dehydrogenase Enzyme)

questions.text: A man presents with high TG and high Chylomicron levels with eruptions on the skin, having eruptive xanthomas. Most likely, he is suffering from:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Familial Hyperlipidemia Type-1Elevated Triglyceride levels will present as “Eruptive Xanthomas”, while Elevated Cholesterol levels will present as “Tendinous Xanthomas”,

choices.text: Liver biopsy and quantitative assay of copper

questions.text: IBQ: KF Ring (?) (For a child suspected to be suffering from Wilson’s Disease) best investigation to confirm diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Liver biopsy and quantitative assay of copper Image shows formation of Kayser-Fleischer rings, due to deposition of copper in the Descemet’s membrane. Quanitative assay of copper levels in hepatic tissue is the confirmatory test for diagnosis of Wilson’s Disease, caused due to the defect in transporter of copper, ATP7A. Increased 24 hour urinary copper, low Serum Ceruloplamsin levels and elevated Serum copper levels are presumptive tests and indicate a strong probability of suffering from Wilson’s disease.

questions.text: A person consumes a diet predominantly of polished rice and pulses. He presents with fatigue and mild neuropathy. What vitamin supplementation should be given for prophylaxis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Vitamin B complex Outer layer of cereals and pulses (bran) is rich in sveral vitamins and minerals. They form one of the chief cources of Vitamin B1 in diet. Using polished rice and pulses over a long duration, where this outer layer has been removed, is likely to result in deficiency of this vitamin. Vitamin B1 deficiency is associated with: a) Beri Beri: Dry/Wet/Infantile b) Wernicke’s Encephalopathy and Wernicke-Korsakoff psychosis

questions.text: You are an intern and want to study coagulation profile, which vacutainer is used for collection of the sample?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) BlueFollowing the correct order of draw of samples in vacutainers is very important to avoid cross contamination of analytes across tubes, which can result in erroneous results due to the varied effects on blood. The correct order in which the different tubes must be used is shown in the figure below:

questions.text: A 10 year old is having extreme muscular weakness particularly on exercising. Hypoglycemia and hepatomegaly is also present. Which Glycogen Storage Disorder?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Von Gierke’s Hypoglycemia associated with both muscle weakness and hepatomegaly is associated with Glycogen Storage Disorder-1 (GSD-1), also known as Von Gierke’s Disease. Kidney enlargement, increased serum uric acid levels and fainting episodes are other important features of this GSD.

questions.text: Which enzyme is deficient in Fabry’s Disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) ?-GalactosidaseSphingolipidoses present with the following common features;• Autosomal recessive Inheritance• Mental retardation• Cherry Red Spot on retina on fundal examination• HepatosplenomegalyFabry’s happens to be an exception, since it shows X-Linked Recessive inheritance pattern, and absence of mental retardation or cherry red spot. The associated enzyme deficiencies for different sphingolipidoses are shown belown:

questions.text: Image with valgum deformity: whole village uses stick for walking has same clinical features. What do you check for?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Check fluoride level Depending on exact details provided in the question, there are two possible scenarios: a) Flourosis due to high levels of fluorine consumption, usually due to water source having high levels. Poisoning can also sometimes happen due to high levels in soil, which contaminate food sources. b) Osteolathyrism due to consumption of large amounts of sweet peas (Lathyrus odoratus) which contains ?-aminopropionitrile (BAPN). Consumtion of Lathyrus Sativus (grass pea/ khesari dal) leads to Neurolathyrism due to presence of BOAA (?—N-oxalyl-amino-L-alanine)

questions.text: Which of the following can eliminate free radical from the body?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Glutathione • Vit E, once oxidised, is recycled by Vit C. • Vit C, once oxidised, is recycled by Glutathione (G-SH). • Glutathione, once oxidised, is recycled by NADPH. Vit E, Vit C, Glutathione and NADPH are the important anti-oxidant molecules, which can eliminate free radical from the body. They are supported by several anti-oxidant enzymes in this process.
